comments:
I have a 64bit Intel CPU 3.6ghz and 64bit Suse Linux 10 edition.. I have downloaded the eclipse-setup-file provided by the site (eclipse-SDK-3.1.2-linux-gtk-x86_64.tar.gz) and extracted it to /usr/eclipse folder with root priviledges.. I have new gtk version and updated the jre but when i try to run eclipse i get the following error message

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
!SESSION 2006-03-27 20:21:30.442 -----------------------------------------------
eclipse.buildId=M20060118-1600
java.version=1.4.2_06
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.
BootLoader constants: OS=linux, ARCH=x86_64, WS=gtk, NL=en_US
Command-line arguments:  -os linux -ws gtk -arch x86_64

!ENTRY org.eclipse.osgi 2006-03-27 20:21:31.621
!MESSAGE Application error
!STACK 1

As shown above the eclipse cannot find the file /usr/eclipse/configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/bundles/85/1/.cp/libswt-pi-gtk-3139.so
which however exists in the specified directory with the exact name mentioned above!!!!!
I have searched for solution to this problem in google and i have seen that other people in 64bit systems encounter the same problem with me 
For example,
http://www.planetamd64.com/lofiversion/index.php/t12898.html
*** Bug 133399 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Please launch eclipse with the options "-console -noExit".  This should leave you with an osgi>.  Run the 'ss' command to print out the installed bundles.  Attach the output to this bug report.

Also can you see if setting the execution bit on the library has any effect?

(In reply to comment #2)
> Please launch eclipse with the options "-console -noExit".  This should leave
> you with an osgi>.  Run the 'ss' command to print out the installed bundles. 
> Attach the output to this bug report.
> 
> Also can you see if setting the execution bit on the library has any effect?
>

(In reply to comment #3)
> (In reply to comment #2)
> > Please launch eclipse with the options "-console -noExit".  This should leave
> > you with an osgi>.  Run the 'ss' command to print out the installed bundles. 
> > Attach the output to this bug report.
> > 
> > Also can you see if setting the execution bit on the library has any effect?
> > 
> Hi!
> I've got the same problem (AMD64, SUSE 10.0 64bit,
> eclipse-SDK-3.1.2-linux-gtk-x86_64.tar.gz with checked MD5 sum).

I've got it running.
Did some searching and found this bug 85699, which gave the right hint for my problem and the solution: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=85699

Another example of a very BAD, misleading error message!!!

Problem:
In fact, I tried to run the 64bit Eclipse/SWTlib with a 32bit JDK which doesn't work obviously and which leads to this BAD and MISLEADING error message! Why isn't there just a JDK version check at startup !!!??? 

Solution:
I've just installed the AMD64 version of JDK 5.0 (jdk1.5.0_06) and used the '-vm /path/to/64bit/java' command line option to start ./eclipse with this JDK -> eclipse runs fine!

Not sure what error we could give you.  The equinox runtime is pure Java and runs on any cpu.  SWT is trying to load their lib and it does not match what was needed.  They can potentially report a better error.  The same is essentially true of all callers to System.loadLibrary (that is, any normal Java code that has related libs).

Moving to SWT to see if they want to do anything special.

It seems to me that the swt fragment should have had a Bundle-NativeCode header (or similar) which referenced the required details for the so. Then when no clause on the native code header matched (e.g. because 32-bit VM used but have a 64-bit so), an appropriate error message could have been published.

I looked at the manifest for the fragment and it has no Bundle-NativeCode header for the so.

Disclaimer: I no almost nothing about how the SWT plugins are arranged :-)

Currently we do not use the OSGi Bundle-NativeCode header at all as there are various problems with the way it works.  The simple statement is that it does not support variables and so requires the host to enumerate/know about all possible supported platforms.  As I recall (could be old info) putting the header in the fragments was also problematic.

The other problem was that the bundle native code elements were agressively extracted and installed at bundle install time.  We have several scenarios where the bundles fro several platforms are present (installed) in a system but may or may not resolve depending on the current running environment (e.g., whether or not the WS is GTK or Motif).  Note here that the WS is not know until (and change at) runtime.  That is, well after installing the bundle

Having said that, we should move to use a standard mechanism as soon as is pratical.  That does not unfortunately help in this case.

Arguably this is the fault of the Linux dynamic linker, it should give
a better errno besides "no such file or directory".  The kernel types I've
asked about this usually say "biarch systems are a bad idea" and blame
the Linux distributions.

I'm marking this as a dup of 85699, we should do some hacky thing where
we check the bits and give a better error message, knowing that it
may not work perfectly everywhere.

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 85699 ***
